fields.headline: Danvers 'devastated' at news of pregnancy
fields.bodyText: Pregnancy is traditionally seen as a cause for celebration. Pink cards are sent depicting storks carrying bundles, in-laws arrive bearing bouquets of flowers, work-mates ring and say they would never have guessed. But not in the Danvers-Smith household. "I was devastated," said Natasha, one of Britain's foremost 400m hurdlers. Such a reaction will not have made her many friends at the antenatal clinic. But among her fellow Olympic hopefuls it must have seemed a perfectly understandable reaction. It has scuppered her chances of going to Athens this summer. Danvers-Smith, 26, who is married to her coach Darrell, said: "I went into a depression stage. I had dreams of what I wanted to do this year. "Wanting to achieve my goals was the whole wide world for me. I could medal at the Olympics. I would have money, recognition - something I have been aiming at for years. "Financially, it will be really, really hard. This year was going to be an investment in my future - our future. Now, instead of making an income, I'm going to be incurring a cost." All had seemed plain sailing until she ran in the first race of her summer build-up. Worried that her body "didn't feel right" she booked a date with her doctor and was told: "You're pregnant, Mrs Smith." "I was the main bread- winner in the family because it's hard for coaches to get rewards in athletics," she said. "At the same time, I would have lost my soul if I had made the decision not to have this child. It would not have fitted at all well with my heart. "But I will come out on the other side. There will be another Olympics. I am really happy and hoping that everything is fine with the baby. It could have been another year but, because I've made what I think constitutes a sacrifice, this child will be very special."
